rows.title: Why is "using namespace std;" considered bad practice?

21:
<p>If you import the right header files you suddenly have names like <a href="http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/io/manip/hex" rel="noreferrer"><code>hex</code></a>, <a href="http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/io/manip/left" rel="noreferrer"><code>left</code></a>, <a href="http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/utility/functional/plus" rel="noreferrer"><code>plus</code></a> or <a href="http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/algorithm/count" rel="noreferrer"><code>count</code></a> in your global scope. This might be surprising if you are not aware that <code>std::</code> contains these names. If you also try to use these names locally it can lead to quite some confusion.</p>

<p>If all the standard stuff is in its own namespace you don't have to worry about name collisions with your code or other libraries.</p>

<p>Another reason is surprise.</p>

<p>If I see <code>cout &lt;&lt; blah</code>, instead of <code>std::cout &lt;&lt; blah</code> I think: What is this <code>cout</code>? Is it the normal <code>cout</code>? Is it something special?</p>

<p>I also consider it a bad practice. Why? Just one day I thought that the function of a namespace is to divide stuff, so I shouldn't spoil it with throwing everything into one global bag.</p>

<p>However, if I often use 'cout' and 'cin', I write: <code>using std::cout; using std::cin;</code> in the .cpp file (never in the header file as it propagates with <code>#include</code>). I think that no one sane will ever name a stream <code>cout</code> or <code>cin</code>. ;)</p>

<p>It's all about managing complexity. Using the namespace will pull things in that you don't want, and thus possibly make it harder to debug (I say possibly). Using std:: all over the place is harder to read (more text and all that).</p>

<p>Horses for courses - manage your complexity how you best can and feel able.</p>

<p>From my experiences, if you have multiple libraries that uses say, <code>cout</code>, but for a different purpose you may use the wrong <code>cout</code>.</p>

<p>For example, if I type in, <code>using namespace std;</code> and <code>using namespace otherlib;</code> and type just <code>cout</code> (which happens to be in both), rather than <code>std::cout</code> (or <code>'otherlib::cout'</code>), you might use the wrong one, and get errors. It's much more effective and efficient to use <code>std::cout</code>.</p>

<p>I do not think it is necessarily bad practice under all conditions, but you need to be careful when you use it.  If you're writing a library, you probably should use the scope resolution operators with the namespace to keep your library from butting heads with other libraries.  For application level code, I don't see anything wrong with it.</p>
<p>With unqualified imported identifiers you need external search tools like <em>grep</em> to find out where identifiers are declared. This makes reasoning about program correctness harder.</p>

<p>This is a bad practice, often known as global namespace pollution. Problems may occur when more than one namespace has the same function name with signature, then it will be ambiguous for the compiler to decide which one to call and this all can be avoided when you are specifying the namespace with your function call like <code>std::cout</code> . Hope this helps. :)   </p>
